segments.text: I had it from February 28th of 61, the day the decision came down, until May Day of 61.
And the moment that the court decision came down, Carl Braden and I, a companion case from Louisville, Kentucky, went from ordinary citizens to become national figures.
The New York Times, for example, the day after this came down, ran three full pages on the majority and minority opinions.
I got back to L.A. and was invited to speak at Berkeley.
I get up there, there's 5,000 people, 5,000 in New York.
Princeton's Wig Clio, the Northwestern University Journalism Department, the
Yale University made Carl May the guest of honor at the law school, and the moot court arguments on our case.
That happened.
And as these things happened, these press releases were funneled back to Hoover.
We now have the record from the agents of the field to Hoover.
Wilkinson spoke in Colorado Springs yesterday.
There were 2,000 people.
That
And Hoover writes across the bottom, when is this going to end?
And somebody writes, contacts him and says, they have another appeal.
Hoover writes, see blank in the Supreme Court and ask when this is over.
When will they be jailed?
And we don't know who blank was in the Supreme Court.
and the report came back, the ACID was followed, filed one more appeal, they'll have at least until May 1st, and Hoover writes, expedite this in every way you can.
Now that is the atmosphere in which we went to jail.
Exactly.
And you have a Jack Kennedy who was gutless and feared, feared Hoover,
who was the most, what's the word, profligate, sex active president we've ever had.
All this was being taped by Hoover just as much as he was taping Martin King's sex.
And these things were all there.
And then you gotta go back to the principles of the Kennedys.
Bobby Kennedy was on the McClellan Committee.
Yeah.
And did, violated all lawyer-client privileges between Jimmy Hoffa and his lawyers.
They have a bad record.
Yeah, I know.
And yet, the image of this young, youthful, bright, what's the, what's the Shakespearean word?
Vigor.
The, you know, the Shakespearean
Camelot atmosphere, that's a lot of bunk.

At any rate, to wind up this point, the Citizens Committee to Preserve American Freedoms lasted from 1952 until it was dissolved in 1960, and dissolved in 1960 because the ideas we'd proved at the local level
were to go national, and four very prominent national leaders decided to form a new committee and hire me as director and put an umbrella over me.
One was Alexander Micklejohn, the former president of Brown and Wisconsin and foremost constitutional philosopher of this century.
and who received the Presidential Medal of Freedom, by the way, from Kennedy in 64.
And he died in 63.
No, he died after he was 63, because he awarded it.
He died when Lyndon Johnson actually gave him the medal.
That was the time when the Presidential Medal of Freedom meant something, before they started giving it to him.
Frank Sinatra for Whitaker Chambers.
Yeah, I know.
Amazing.
Mikkel John was the philosophical giant.
He is the one that reached my conscience from probably 1952 to 1955 or 1956.
I had no sharp First Amendment basis for my ethics.
If the
Un-American Activities Committee had gone after maybe somebody on the far right.
I might not have fought as hard.
In 1955, Michael John testified before the Hennings Committee of the United States Senate, in which he spelled out the limits of free speech.
It's a wonderful testimony, a very brief essay, and I read it.
And we invited him to one of our meetings where we were defending the foreign born, some religious leaders in LA.
And I heard him.
He was then 85 when I first met him.
And he completely turned my life around.
In fact, I said when I met him, if I ever get a subpoena from UAC myself, I'll go to jail on the First Amendment if necessary.
And that was literally said by me in 56.
The other person was Aubrey Williams.
Aubrey Williams was the director of the National Youth Administration.
He was the head of the WPA under Harry Hopkins.
He and Harry Hopkins and A. Philip Randolph, through Eleanor Roosevelt, were able to get a wartime FEBC ordinance through, through Roosevelt.
Aubrey was a social worker from Montgomery, Alabama, educated at the University of Wisconsin at Madison.
He was an extreme bread baiter.
He was caught up in the Cold War as much as anybody I've ever known.
Very significant.
Because toward the end of his life, he himself
was called before the Eastland Committee at the time that Eastland was trying to put the red label on Aubrey's next-door neighbor, Virginia Dewar, who in turn was the sister-in-law of Hugo Black.
Aubrey began learning in the early 50s, and when he got out of the WPA and Roosevelt put him in to be head of rural electrification,
he could not get confirmed because of the red-braiding atmosphere in the country.
Aubrey, while he was head of the WPA, would fire somebody on the rumor that they were communists.
By 1960, he hired me, at a time when I would not answer the question anymore.
And I remember so well, we're starting this thing out,
He said, I want to get some prominent politicians.
I don't trust Jimmy Roosevelt.
He's no good.
I'd already had bad experience with Jimmy.
So he said, I think Chet Holifield would be a good person to be one of the co-chairs of this committee with me.
So he went to see Chet Holifield, who was the congressperson from Montebello, California, later to become the head of the Atomic Energy subcommittees in the House.
And apparently, John Olivefield, who I had known very well in the housing days, in fact, he came to me and I hired his daughter to get her a job when she was a student.
But by 1960, Olivefield said that he would do it, but only if I would say I wasn't a communist.
In other words, he was giving me the true loyalty oath.
Aubrey wrote me that I got Chet today.
He's willing.
All I need from you is a brief statement saying you're not a communist.
He sent it to me in L.A. And I figured this is more of the same stuff I'd seen from 48 forward.
And I wrote back to Aubrey a two-page letter saying, Aubrey, you know, I've
I'm not going to answer this question to Chet or anyone else.
I've been through too much.
I'm going to jail on this issue probably within another year.
I'm not going to start answering it away from the committee for the convenience of a politician like Chet Holifield.
Aubrey writes back my special delivery, and we used to use that kind of mail, saying, Frank, I see, I know your principles, I know you won't answer.
but I see in the second paragraph on the second page that you really are telling me you're not a communist."
And I sit down, I write a special delivery back to Aubrey saying, there's nothing in the second page in the second paragraph that tells you any more than Chet, the answer to that question.
So Aubrey sends a telegram back, to hell with Chet, let's go.
And from then on, we never had the loyalty
test within the Committee to Abolish UAC, and we had hundreds of supporters, and people from people who were very radical and probably were communist to people who were anti-communist.
We just refused to have a political litmus test in our own program to get rid of UAC.
Sure.
That's what ACNU was doing, it's what ADA was doing, it's what
The NAACP were doing the all, you signed up at ACNU at that time.
Yeah.
You had this where you're not a member of a communist, totalitarian, what about the organization.
The third person in this group, these names are important, to each play a function on our success.
Mikkel John is the moral leader.
He's the philosopher.
He is the purist and the absolutist on the First Amendment.
He's the one who taught me absolutism on the first.
Aubrey is the practical wheeler-dealer, Harry Hopkins, who knows how to get things done in Washington.
He often told me he only made one mistake in his life.
He said, that's when I hired, I was looking for an N.Y.A.
director in Texas.
I heard about this fellow, a teacher out at San Marcos School, and I hired him.
And then he went on to be president, and I'm sorry ever since.
He told me that just before he died in the midst of the Vietnam War.
Third person was Clarence Pickett of the Quakers, the American Friends Service Committee, who was the nonviolent, pacifist, loving type.
So our campaigns were never, there was no rhetoric, no nailing-to-the-wall rhetoric in our campaign.
It was all solid, principled, First Amendment, constitutional arguments.
No mean stuff.
No mean stuff, no anger in our movement.
The fourth guy is an unbelievable character.
They're all dead.
He's a retired Wall Street banker from Wandsville, New Jersey.
His wife's father, uncle, brother are all state Supreme Court judges.
But in 1948, this guy left Wall Street, had a good sum of money, retired next to the Lawrenceville School there outside of Princeton, and got involved with Henry Wallace, and ran for U.S.
Senator from New Jersey on the Progressive Ticket, and that nailed him to the ground.
From then on, he was worse than the ordinary garden bride.
He was a Henry Wallace communist.
These four men hired me.
And that's where the campaign started.
It took us 15 years, from 1960 to 1975, before we finally abolished the committee.
We now know, from the FBI record, in our damage section of our lawsuit,

although we're not any longer seeking substantive damages, but we would be able to prove, I think, that we could have abolished UAC in five years if the Un-American Activities Committee had left us alone, if the, not only Un-American, if the FBI had left us alone and let us go into the marketplace and just settle our arguments
without having the FBI coming in to disrupt and poison the atmosphere around us.
How did the FBI work on poisoning the atmosphere?

Did they send in agents who would get agitators to go to your meetings and whip up the crowd, or did they hand out leaflets, or did they make charges against you that appeared in the press mysteriously, or what were the tactics that they used?
you know enough about the record to have listed the four major categories.
The FBI concentrated, you know, you have to realize that our file is as tall as a seven story building.
And they, I've got my first 4,500 pages, a little pile in that picture there.
In that pile alone,
The FBI reports their success in getting 46 of my meetings canceled by going ahead of me to a community to try to get people who invited me to withdraw and cancel.
They had me banned in Wisconsin, in Minnesota, in Ohio State, at the University of North Carolina, in Michigan State.
All of these things, I never, never dreamed it was the FBI.
I said over and over again, we're living in a McCarthy atmosphere.
You have to understand that people are frightened and fearful.
And that's what happens.
And every time they did ban me, we just turned it around to our advantage.
And they banned me at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.
I was speaking the night before in Manhattan, Connecticut, a little town in Connecticut, at a house meeting.
In the middle of my meeting, there were twelve people in the living room.
There was a phone call that came through person-to-person collect for me from Durham, from students in Duke Law School, wanting to know if I'd be willing to speak at Duke Law School tomorrow.
I said, no, I'd love to, but I'm speaking at Chapel Hill.
you know, 20 miles down the road.
And they said, oh, no, you're not.
You've just been banned.
Governor Dan Moore has banned you.
I said, well, I don't know anything about this.
They said, well, you better take our word for it.
We want to make you the guest of honor at Duke Law School tomorrow at the time you're supposed to speak at Chapel Hill and are banned.
I said, well, if this is the situation, talk to, and I named a law professor that I knew at Duke.
And when I get down there, when I arrive, we'll talk about it.
When I got there, I had been banned, so I went to Duke.
They had a packed auditorium in the Duke Law School.
Twenty-five television stations covered it.

Then we went in a caravan up to Chapel Hill, and the students at Chapel Hill had put a long streamer along a little two-foot-high wall on the sidewalk in the main town, calling it Governor Dan Moore's Wall.
And they arranged for me to stand on the sidewalk and speak over the top of the sidewalk to 2,000 students.
And then from there to the Wesley Foundation and the Hillel Foundation and to the Newman Club, I spoke to thousands and thousands of people.
If I'd gone down there alone, I probably would have hit 35 students.

So you could turn, in other words, you know that the FBI got a hold of the governor and put the pressure on him, and so he put pressure on UNC, the president at UNC, and so the president at UNC banned it, and what that did is you worked it to your advantage.
Well, but not because I knew about the FBI.
Right.
I turned McCarthyism, as I understood it, to my advantage.
Fight back.
Now, I mentioned 5,000 students turning out at my first meeting when the decision came down in 1961 at Berkeley.
What really happened at Berkeley, I learned two years ago.
The FBI was responsible for that mass meeting.
I was home in Los Angeles.
I got a call from
a couple of students saying there was an organization called COPE, or something like that.
I guess that's the word.
SCOPE, or the acronym for some student organization in Berkeley.
When I come up and speak, there's 35 people in their group, I said, I'd love to come up and speak.
I thought that was really neat.
First time I'd been invited to speak, I'd never spoken on this subject.
Here I am, on my way to jail,
I get in touch with Mikkel John, who lives in Berkeley, and we go together.
We walk through Sathergate, and there are thousands of people.
I'm still looking for a room number where 35 students are going to hear me.
A television camera is put in my face and asks what I have to say, and I find out that the meeting had been moved to Wheeler Auditorium,
and then they piped it into two more auditoriums, and then everything from Wheeler down to Sathergate, with loudspeakers, there was 5,000 people out there to hear me.
Humor about this.
With Mikkel John with me, he's then 89, he weighed about 89 pounds, and I don't have any notes, or know nothing.
I hear him speak before 5,000 people.
So I turned to him,
I said, Alec, I'll introduce you, and you tell them about your Hennings essay.
That's what sent me to jail.
He said, oh no, Frank, this is your day, or something like that.
I wanted like a hole in the head.
So we're going, walking up to this huge crowd of people, everybody's staring at us, to Wheeler Auditorium.
We're going backstage, and Mikkel John was trying to tell me what to say.
And you've got a picture of him.
He's just a tiny little diminutive man.
He said, Frank, tell him about Thoreau and Emerson.
Well, I'd never read Thoreau and Emerson.
He didn't know it until that moment.
So he proceeds to tell me the anecdote about Thoreau being in jail, and Emerson coming to visit him, saying, what are you doing in there?
Henry, and Thoreau says, what are you doing out there, Ralph?
You know the story?
Crazy.
And I said, oh, Alec.
And he said, you didn't know that I said, no, I, sorry, Alec.
He said, well, you get up there and make the best speech you can.
And once you're in prison, I'll send you the books so you know why you're in there.
The moment I hit Atlanta, he started me out on Plato
He gave me a reading regimen, and it was so exhausting that I thought I'd never finish it.
I was still in Milton, Paradise Lost, and Areopagitica after three months struggling.
And I kept saying, when do we get the Constitution?
He said, never mind, it'll come.
Anyway, I learned why I was in prison by reading while I was in prison on Micklejohn's thing.
But better get back to the FBI.
And did you learn why the crowd was that large at Berkeley?
That is only what I've just learned two years ago.
We now have the FBI documents.
This is the moment that the people from SCOPE, or whatever it was, had called me.
The FBI went to Clark Kerr, the president.
Was this about 1960?
One.
Yeah, okay, I know that group that you're talking about.
Michael Tiger was one of them.
He's a lawyer in Washington now.
He clerked for William O. Douglas.
Bright kids.
Anyway, we now have the documents where the FBI, under Hoover's orders, when he hears I'm picking up there, goes to Clark Kerr to get me cancelled.
Tells him to cancel the meeting.
And Clark Kerr hands it over to a deputy
administrator and deputy president of the university.
And the president writes back to Hoover saying, we cannot cancel this.
It's a legitimate student organization.
And Hoover insists that they do.
And Clark Kerr tells, tell Hoover that we'll pay his way here to speak and debate Wilkinson or come before or afterwards to speak on behalf of the FBI.
and it comes back, and Hoover sees that memorandum of Clark Kerr and writes across the face of it.
Absolutely not.
I never trusted that Clark Kerr, that, what do you call him, those liberals, those poly-liberals, or some word.
It's in the handwriting.
I never trusted Clark Kerr and those others, and his deputy is another one.
So when they couldn't do that to them, then they went to a fundamentalist group called the Baptist Fundamentalists in the Bay Area, connected with the 20th Century Reformation Hour.
And they come to the university to get me canceled.
And Clark Kerr turns them down.
Then they get a caravan of 125 cars.
And they leave the Berkeley campus with signs plastered all over the cars, Stop Communist Convict Wilkinson from speaking.
And they go 125 miles to Sacramento and go around the state capitol and go in to see Governor Brown Sr. And Governor Brown upholds my right to speak.
No one told me anything about this until I arrived with Mikkel John and finally there was a crowd.
So then they come back and they go round and round and round the campus.
And by the time I arrived,
The FBI, through this fundamentalist right group, had attracted so much attention that 5,000 people turned out to see my horns.
One would think that with all the money and men of the FBI
They could be more efficient.
Well, you know, I've spoken... As a free society, though, and you just...
I spoke at this wonderful conference on the right of dissent at Harvard Law School last Saturday.
And my topic was the statutory basis of repression.
In preparing for that, I went back through this whole life of mine
You know, I'm a case.
It's Wilkinson versus U.S. Now there's another case, Wilkinson v. FBI.
And I went back to those hearings in Georgia in 56, 58.
And I find out we'd agreed with the ACLU, all I would do was to, they ask your name and address.
You give my name, but not my address.
My name is Frank Wilkinson.
Your address, please.
On the base of the First Amendment, I refuse to answer this question or any other question of your committee.

At that point, Richard Ahrens, the fundamentalist right-wing general counsel of the UAC, puts in two and a half pages of the congressional record where the contempt citation was voted, laying a legislative framework for having brought the question to me.
It is not a witch hunt, because I'm down there trying to keep HUAC from putting the red label on Martin King.
It is entirely that we are investigating oversight regarding the recent court decisions affecting the Internal Security Act of 1950, Title I, Title II, the Voorhees Act, the
Smith Act, etc.
They were all checking those laws out, and therefore they had to ask questions in order to advise Congress on how to improve the laws.
Every bit of it was done with a statutory basis.
But you get the FBI files on me.
There were 12 separate prosecutive summaries sent by Hoover to the Justice Department to prosecute me.
Never just
I mean, I would say that he hated my integration work, and he didn't like my work to abolish the Inter-American Identities Committee.
And so it's a personal vendetta on an individual.
And when you get these prosecuting summaries, which I have, there are six of them in that pile of papers you have right there.
Under the FOIA, you get these documents.
In every case, it's not just a wild...

accusation against me they claimed that under the fbi's responsibility to enforce the federal criminal statutes namely smith act the police act security act county's control act we have investigated mr wilkins and we find that he is guilty of so-and-so they provide what all the agents that were following me at that time turn in all their stuff
Hoover puts it into one three-page summary and turns it over for prosecution for my violating one of the acts.
It's very important to know it's done that way.
And then each of these was rejected.

Twelve separate attorneys general, both Republican and Democrat, write back to Hoover saying the evidence you have submitted shows no indication of violation of federal criminal statutes on the part of Mr. Wilkinson.
I throw this out to you because now we're building up a similar legislative history regarding the use of the word terrorism, and that's really the argument that I was making in Harvard.
Because these witch hunts, these inquisitorial committees, these repressive laws
are all done by men and women who maintain the pretense that we're a system, a government of laws.
Yeah.
It isn't just like, go get them, go smear them, go get Martin Luther King's sex life, go cop them.
They always give you a legislative basis for doing what they're doing.
And now that those laws have been declared
either unconstitutional or unenforceable, which all of them have been.

When they get around to 1981, five years after HUAC is abolished and Strom Thurmond revives HUAC in the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee, they find that there is no statutory basis that's solid enough in the word communism
or certainly the word un-American, which doesn't even fly anymore.
So it's called the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Terrorism.
And when Hoover dies in 72, and Gerald Ford knocks out the FBI's quintile probe on political surveillance, and begins to turn the FBI around to a federal bureau of
criminal investigation.
It was his attorney general, Levy, under Ford, that gives us the protections.
But in 1983, William Fred Smith, attorney general under Reagan, now Meese, writes new guidelines that overturns Gerald Ford's guidelines.
I think it's important.
that it's a Republican today who's turning the clock back on a good Republican we had in 1976.
And Reagan's new guidelines state that the FBI shall investigate all violations of federal criminal law, which is where they should stop.
Nothing more, except maybe to repeal what we call the speech crimes.
But get rid of the speech crimes and enforce the law.
That's what the FBI should do.
But then he doesn't.
That is point A.
B, the FBI shall investigate all terrorist enterprises.
And that is the basis of what Mies is doing in infiltrating the church movement, the sanctuary, the Central America Peace Movement, and so on.
The only thing I want to add for this record, and I did it not in Texas, where it might be popular, but I did it in Massachusetts in...
Ted Kennedy's home district, a block away from the Kennedy School of Government.

The guidelines that Ronald Reagan and William Brent Smith formalized in March of 1983 were copied after an original draft, which was never approved, done by Jimmy Carter in 1979 under his attorney general, Ben Civilletti,
And the Carter Charter was written by and introduced by Senator Ted Kennedy.
It was the liberals, Kennedy, Carter, Civilletti, that first came up with this loose word, terrorist enterprise, which goes to the heart of political dissent.
It is undefined.
I mean, we have all the laws we need for the FBI to stop terrorism.
dynamiting, possession, kidnapping, hijacking.
Those were all the books.
Let the FBI enforce the law.
That's what is needed.
The church committee, late Senator Frank Church, committee report, which is so valuable, sort of the bible of the abuse of power by J. Edgar Hoover.
They brought out the fact that in Chicago, from 1966 to
The FBI had 1,012 informants, political informants, on political surveillance in Chicago.
They spent $2,500,000 paying those informants.
During that period of time, there were over 1,000 gangland murders in Chicago that were never caught by the FBI.
in New York at the same time.
There was one period in New York where the FBI had 404 agents on the communist detail, and only four on organized crime.
This is fact.
This is out of congressional?
Church Valley Report.
Okay.
Very basic.
Incredible.
The American Bar Association
which, you know, is the respectable bar unit, you know, the officers of the court in our old system, did a critique of William French Smith's guidelines in 1983.
And they asked correctly, why the need for this special focus on terrorism?
Why does there need to be a special
but why not just the federal criminal statutes?
And they invite Judge Webster, the current director of the FBI, to come before the ABA and to tell them, what is the need for this?
Do you need extra money to fight terrorism?
And what is the empirical data to support such a concentration drive on domestic terrorism?
And Judge Webster
tells the ABA, this is a better public record, I do not need any more money to fight terrorism.
Terrorism is a low priority.
In 1981 there were, these are very close to exact, in 1981 there were 51 terrorist cases in the United States.
In 1982 there were 40.
Well, there's no basis for it.
It's a guise for silencing dissent.
The international terrorist problem is being exploited by Reagan and by expedients, by Carter and Kennedy, as a means of rationalizing some control on dissent in this country.
And, you know, I give this to you hurriedly in my capsule, but I've prepared very carefully for my lecture here.
I'm dealing with 300 of the brightest young law students in the country last Saturday.
And I look at them, they're all, you know, under 25.
They don't know these things.
I know it.
So I went back and pulled out the statutory, the legislative history to show
how their generation is going to be impacted by these Reagan guidelines unless they get involved in civil liberties work and fight for the right to dissent.
I have another question, and that is, that deals with the relationship between you and your organization, National Committee to Abolish HUAC,
And the other one that you repeat, I don't get the question.
I have another question.

And that is the relationship between the National Committee to Abolish HUAC and then Carl and the movement, the anti-war movement, the women's liberation movement, the civil rights movement, what's basically called the movement in the 1960s.
What kinds of roles
I know that you were working still very diligently to abolish HUAC during that time, but what else did you, and did you join in?
What kind of relations did you have with the anti-war movement, the student movement, etc.?
It's a very, very thoughtful question, because much of those movements in the 60s had an element that was anti-
the word, not legislative politics, but electoral politics.
Anti-electoral politics.
My own kids, for example, dropped out of Cal and San Francisco State to become trade unions.
The academic world was not real.
And many, many people were turned off by electoral politics.
The idea of lobbying to influence a member of Congress
to stop the Vietnam War, or in our case, to abolish UAC, it's like we're hopelessly nave people who don't know what's going on.
Yeah.
We held our, N. Carl's strength has been focused.
Our strength is the fact that we're absolutist on principle.
We do not deviate a bit in regard
to the political content of the Bill of Rights.
We do not, as many people say, well, you know, all speech is all right except maybe a little bit, we ought to do something about the Nazis or the plan.
We don't ever get near that.
On wiretapping, where Ted Kennedy came up with a wiretapping bill a couple years ago, we fought it.
All right, that's one thing.
The second thing is,
that we focus.
We take the most imminent and dangerous issue for civil liberties at any one time, and then we focus.
We don't try to cover the whole field.
Now, during the 60s, we always have argued that civil liberties are indivisible to peace.
Civil liberties are indivisible to civil rights, or whatever the movements are.
During the civil rights struggles, Ann Braden, N. Carl officer, wrote our booklet called HUAC, Bulwark of Segregation, in which we brought together the civil rights movement and civil liberties.
Today on our board of officers, we have John Lewis, the first president of SNCC, Julian Bond, the PR guy in SNCC, now a senator in Georgia,
C.T.
Vivian, who was director of affiliates for Martin Luther King.
They're all our officers because we related the civil rights struggles with civil liberties.
And Martin King's statement the night we went to jail is the classic.
On the peace movement, always the same, but we had to do an awful lot of education.
In 1962, right after I got out of prison, I came back to Los Angeles.
And you held a hearing against students at three of our colleges, some student peace activity or I don't know what it was.
Yeah.
We had done such an organizing job among students that when the hearing was held, we had the long-standing federal building surrounded on four sides that makes
20 story building, four of us were students going around there.
Beautiful demonstration, something you never saw during the silent fifties.
It came by 62.
It began in 1960 when we had the first demonstration.
I'm actually accused of organizing the so-called riot at San Francisco City Hall where the students were washed down the stairs of the city hall.
That's when it began, after Carol Chessman, and after the Greensboro Civil Rights guy.
I trace all of the development of the student movements to the Greensboro black students who fought for the World Restoration.
I think that's where it began.
But by 1962, they're there.
Now, that morning, I've been working for years with a group starting about 1960.
called Women Strike for Peace, headed up by Dagmar Wilson.
They were fighting Kennedy at that point for his bomb test in the Pacific, and getting nowhere with it.

And so they had decided, as a tactic, that if anyone should read in the papers that Kennedy had dropped another bomb in South Pacific, I mean a test of a bomb in the South Pacific, that without any further word,
All 100 members of WISP, Women's Strike for Peace, would come to the federal building.
They'd wear white dresses, and they'd carry a red rose or a yellow rose, something like that, and do a vigil against Kennedy.
The night before the U.S. hearings began, Kennedy dropped a bomb, passed a bomb.
The next morning, promptly at 9 o'clock, from all over the city, without even a phone call, are 100 women in white dresses,
with little red roses to protest.
They get down there, and they can't get near the Federal Building because the students are four abreast all around it.
They don't know the students.
They do know me.
So they call me, come across the street to them, and they said, Frank, Kennedy has tested another bomb.
We're down here to do a vigil.
Could you ask the students to make some room so we can do a vigil in front of the Federal Building there against Kennedy?"
And I turned and said, look at that.
How can you, how can you do that?
There's no place you can, the building, the headline of the day said, HUAC used a freight elevator.
You can get in the building.
They had to use a freight elevator to get into the building.
I said, come on over and join them.
And they said, no, that would confuse the issues between HUAC and the Kennedy bomb testing.
We cannot confuse the issues.
That was April of 62.
On December the 6th of 62, I got a phone call from Dagmar Wilson in Washington saying, HUAC has just subpoenaed
the entire leadership of Women's Strike for Peace, will you come back and help us?"
And I went back to help.
They didn't need any help.
